output.conclusion: By completing this course, participants will gain a comprehensive understanding of the threats posed by quantum computers to existing cryptographic systems and the techniques used to develop and implement quantum-safe encryption solutions. They will be equipped to contribute to the development and deployment of secure systems in the post-quantum era.
output.introduction: This advanced course provides a deep dive into the emerging field of quantum-safe encryption, also known as post-quantum cryptography. Designed for experts in cryptography, cybersecurity, and related fields, the course explores the vulnerabilities of current encryption algorithms to quantum computers and the cryptographic solutions being developed to address these threats. The course covers the mathematical foundations, algorithmic details, and practical implementation considerations of various post-quantum cryptographic schemes.

chapters.chapterTitle: Introduction to Quantum Computing and Cryptography
chapters.description: Overview of quantum computing principles, including qubits, superposition, and entanglement. Introduction to Shor's algorithm and its impact on RSA and ECC. Discussion of Grover's algorithm and its implications for symmetric key cryptography.

chapters.chapterTitle: The Threat Landscape: Quantum Attacks on Classical Cryptography
chapters.description: Detailed analysis of the vulnerabilities of RSA, ECC, and AES to quantum attacks. Exploration of the timeline for quantum computer development and the urgency of transitioning to quantum-safe cryptography. Discussion of the economic and security implications of delayed adoption.

Introduction to lattice-based cryptography. Explanation of mathematical concepts such as lattices, shortest vector problem (SVP), and closest vector problem (CVP). Discussion of the hardness assumptions underlying lattice-based schemes.

Detailed examination of lattice-based key exchange and digital signature algorithms, including CRYSTALS-Kyber and CRYSTALS-Dilithium. Analysis of the security properties and performance characteristics of these algorithms.
Introduction to code-based cryptography. Explanation of error-correcting codes, including McEliece and Niederreiter cryptosystems. Discussion of the hardness assumptions based on decoding problems.
Detailed examination of code-based encryption and signature algorithms. Analysis of the security properties and performance characteristics of these algorithms, including the Classic McEliece scheme.
Introduction to multivariate cryptography. Explanation of multivariate quadratic (MQ) equations and the hardness of solving MQ systems. Discussion of the Rainbow signature scheme.
Introduction to hash-based signatures. Explanation of Merkle trees and the Winternitz one-time signature scheme. Discussion of the SPHINCS+ signature scheme and its security properties.

Practical considerations for implementing quantum-safe cryptographic algorithms in software and hardware. Discussion of performance optimization techniques and security best practices. Analysis of the challenges of transitioning existing systems to post-quantum cryptography.

Overview of the NIST Post-Quantum Cryptography Standardization process. Discussion of the selected algorithms and their potential impact on industry standards. Exploration of the deployment challenges and strategies for integrating quantum-safe cryptography into existing infrastructure.
